Description: Upper body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably an amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of chariot horses to right and male figure to left (of horses, part of two heads with added white dots on bridles and part of mane in added red; of male figure facing left, a groom, set at a lower level, there survives face with red fillet in hair, red beard, white freckles on cheek, and part of red himation).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For parallels regarding the horses, see CVA Oxford II, Group IIIH, pl. III,9.
The cheeks markings suggest a foreign origin for the groom.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 465, no. B793)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 40, pl. XX, no. 21)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0895)
